author: garfreeek

text: It's not really all that recycled. The dungeons are there embedded and they are really interesting. It's just that the overworld, instead of being a giant map was condensed and more compact within those three areas. It was a nice change-up but I think it should have been supported by a bigger and more heavily populated skyworld. I wanted the sky to be comparable to the Great Sea but it felt more like a small hub. Pity.
author: Dan Buck

text:
In time we will all praise it's awesome use of wii motion+ and great bad guy (girahim, is that right?!) 

The constant recycling of three levels is what made me wonder how the hell it took them this long to make the thing, it's not like there is an overworld or a bunch of sidequests!

author: my pp small , i was cucked and

text:
I was playing GC classics such as Wind Waker for the first time, at your age! Ahh, the good old days. 
Anyway, I can agree with what you're saying, in some ways. Certain games from my childhood don't seem nearly as enjoyable any more, and not because they're inadequate games. Being a naive kid is a great advantage in our enjoyment of life! That being said, most Nintendo games (Galaxy 1+2 being prime examples) make me feel like a kid again. Very few things have that effect!
author: YummyBananaFish

text: I liked 2 more than 1, but both Super Mario Galaxy games are must plays.  I can understand why some people liked 1 more than 2 I just wasn't one of them.
author: Matt 6418

text: Well, it might have something to do with the fact that I was 7 when I got Galaxy 1. I was still a young tyke who saw the world as colorful. Flash forward a couple years, and I was a much more knowledgeable 11 year old. I was expecting Galaxy 2 to replicate my wonderful and already nostalgic memories of Galaxy 1, and I just didn't get that feeling.
